hypotheses: H1: A younger population (lower median age) leads to higher rates of new business formation.
H2: Older societies reduce entrepreneurship at all ages via a 'rank effect' that slows younger workers' acquisition of business skills.
H3: The relationship between age and the propensity to start a business is an inverted-U (entrepreneurship rises with age up to a point, then declines).
claim.hypotheses_location: Theory and model section (Propositions and Corollaries) and Introduction; specifically stated in the theoretical propositions (Proposition 1, Corollary 1, Corollary 2, Proposition 2, Proposition 3/4) in the paper's theory section.
claim.statement: Younger societies have higher entrepreneurship rates; a one standard deviation decrease in a country's median age increases new business formation by 2.5 percentage points (about 40% of the mean rate).
claim.statement_location: Abstract and Introduction; empirical results section reporting GEM regressions (results summary and Table discussions where the 2.5 percentage point effect is reported).

data.source: Primary: Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM); Validation/comparison: Flash Eurobarometer Survey on Entrepreneurship (FESE). Additional country-level data: Penn World Table (GDP), Barro and Lee (education attainment), World Bank and Property Rights Alliance (start-up costs, property rights), U.S. Census Bureau International Data Base (population statistics for sampling weights).
data.wave_or_subset: GEM individual-level data covering roughly 2001–2010 (paper mentions GEM 2001–2010 and summary tables for years including 2002–2009); country-year sample of 393 observations; OECD subset of 230 observations; summary stats by year provided in Appendix (Table C2).
data.sample_size: 393 country-year observations (overall sample); GEM covers 82 countries across 2001–2010 (paper reports yearly country counts in Table C2).
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual-level entrepreneurship indicators aggregated to country-year and country-age cells; regressions use country-year (and country-age) observations (weighted by cell population).
data.notes: Observations are weighted by number of individuals in each country-age-year cell; standard errors clustered at the country level. Multiple entrepreneurship definitions used (early-stage businesses, high-aspiration entrepreneurship, etc.). The paper constructs a demographic shrinkage parameter r from age distributions and uses median age and proportions younger than a given age (s_a). Appendix D contains Japan corporate-rank age distributions; Table C2 provides year-by-year summary statistics. Correlation between GEM and FESE country-year entrepreneurship rates is reported as 0.50.

method.description: The paper develops a theoretical demographic model linking population age structure (via parameter r and age distribution measures) to entrepreneurship through two mechanisms: youth-related advantages and accumulated business acumen tied to workforce rank. Empirically, the authors test model predictions using GEM individual-level survey data aggregated to country-year and age cells. Reduced-form regressions relate entrepreneurship rates to the demographic shrinkage parameter r, median age, and the share of population younger than specified ages (s_a), with year dummies and a variety of controls; robustness checks use FESE and alternative entrepreneurship definitions. Standard errors are clustered at the country level and observations are weighted by cell population. Some specifications include country fixed effects.
steps: Obtain GEM individual-level data (country, year, age, entrepreneurship indicators) and supplementary country-level datasets (Penn World Table, Barro and Lee, World Bank indices, Property Rights Alliance, IDB population statistics).
Construct demographic measures: shrinkage parameter r from age distribution, median age, and s_a (share of population younger than age a).
Aggregate individual-level entrepreneurship indicators to country-year and country-age cells and compute entrepreneurship rates (early-stage, high-aspiration, alternative definitions).

Run reduced-form OLS regressions of entrepreneurship rates on r (or median age) and s_a, including year dummies and additional control variables; weight observations by cell population and cluster standard errors at the country level.
Estimate age-specific regressions (or include age dummies and age-squared) to document the inverted-U relationship and to test differential effects across ages.
Conduct robustness checks: include country fixed effects, alternative entrepreneurship definitions, compare results using FESE data, and check OECD-only subsamples.
Report effect sizes (e.g., impact of one standard deviation change in median age) and illustrate predicted entrepreneurship across countries (e.g., Japan vs U.S. predictions).
method.models: Reduced-form linear regressions (OLS) of entrepreneurship rates on demographic variables (r, median age, s_a), age dummies and polynomial age specifications for inverted-U; some specifications include country fixed effects; standard errors clustered by country; weighted regressions by cell population. Theoretical model: a demographic human-capital model linking rank and age to entrepreneurship (propositions and corollaries).
method.outcome_variable: Entrepreneurship rate (primarily early-stage business formation rate as measured in GEM; variants include high-aspiration entrepreneurship and other GEM/FESE definitions).
method.independent_variables: Primary: demographic shrinkage parameter r, median age, share of population younger than a (s_a), age (and age squared/polynomial).
method.control_variables: Log per capita GDP, GDP growth, agricultural share of GDP, education attainment (Barro and Lee), start-up costs, property rights indices, compulsory military service (included in some specifications and interactions with r), year dummies; some specifications include country fixed effects.

results.summary: Theoretical and empirical results show that demographic structure strongly affects entrepreneurship. A younger population increases entrepreneurship rates both via composition (higher share of young people) and via a rank effect that raises entrepreneurship at any age. Empirically, a one standard deviation decrease in median age is associated with a 2.5 percentage point increase in new business formation (~40% of the mean entrepreneurship rate). The negative effect of aging (higher r or median age) persists across specifications, definitions of entrepreneurship, and in both GEM and FESE datasets. The relation between age and entrepreneurship is inverted-U shaped, peaking in the late 20s to mid-30s (paper reports a peak around age 32). Middle-aged cohorts are most sensitive to demographic aging. Country examples: predicted entrepreneurship rate for Japan (r = 0.22) is ~2.3%, whereas for the U.S. (r = 0.10) it is ~3.7%.
